Smarmy, thats it. Thats describes what I hate about him perfectly.

He's a self righteous prick though. That's why people don't like him. Telling Jon Jones to get his shit together and "get his academics in order" so he can "return to the classroom." It's not only a lame as fuck insult, but who the fuck is he to lay that judgement? He knows Jon Jones will beat his ass again. And he tries to portray himself as a good guy and role model, and gets bothered when people don't see him that way. I don't like that at all. It's self-righteous. Nobody gives a fuck that he's a "good dad" and a "role model." Being good to fans is important and being a good fighter is important . We watch the sport because we want to see good fights, not because the fighters we are watching are good role models and parents. He's lame as fuck.
Edit: not saying he's not a great fighter, obviously he is. I respect his hard work and skill as a fighter, but he's just not likeable to me. He's like your new stepdad that tries to lecture you on how you should behave. He rubs me the wrong way.

No I don't agree that it's bad. I just don't think that the fact you have unlimited time makes any difference to the story at all. You have to beat Ganon when you're ready, it's the player's job to determine when that is. If you never face Ganon then I guess it breaks the story but like I said most people wouldn't do that because they'd wanna fight Ganon.

Most people I'd venture to guess finish the divine beasts, do a bunch of shrines and upgrade some stuff and get some weapons and go face Ganon. If you're gonna go explore for months at a time before facing Ganon that's your own prerogative , but don't complain it doesn't fit in with the story. It simply would not be fun to play if you couldn't spend as much time as you want exploring. I probably put 50 hours into the game before I fought Ganon. Finished the beasts, unlocked the map, did a bunch of shrines and got ready to fight him. I've spent the last 50 hours just exploring the world after besting Ganon. Technically yeah, Ganon is "still there" and I'm just screwing around but idc at this point, I beat the game.
I'm willing to sacrifice a little bit of immersion for fun gameplay. If I was rushed to go fight Ganon and couldn't explore, the game would suck. It's very, very common for games to do this anyways and nobody really cares. In all reality almost any game time being unlimited doesn't make a whole lot of sense but you ignore that because it doesn't really matter. I don't think this is a legitimate complaint at all. Is it realistic that Link doesn't have to sleep or eat or take a shit? No, but I don't care. The game tells you to fight Ganon when you are ready, but not to take too long. I don't think it's necessary to actually put in time constraints because the player should intrinsically want to face Ganon. It's basic to any game to want to finish it.

The point isn't to get to Ganon as fast as possible. They even tell you in the game not to face Ganon until you are ready. You're advised not to fave him until you free the divine beasts and are strong enough to face him. Yes the player can choose to just explore and never fight Ganon, but that's more mechanics than story. The whole point is to build yourself to a point where you can face Ganon and then go do it. You can face Ganon whenever, but you cannot fail so you have to be ready. Also, having a timer would make this game not fun at all. There would be no reason to have it open world. As far as the story goes, yeah it's very minimal but that doesn't make it bad. The idea that you lost your memories and had to recover them was interesting. The memories were enjoyable and the characters were unique and memorable even though they weren't fully fleshed out. It leaves to the imagination.

Zelda has had Ganon trapped for 100 years. She's losing power and there's not a ton of time left but that's relative. It's not like you only have a few days or a week.
Edit: also there doesn't really need to be an explanation as to why Ganon is evil. Ganon is literally the embodiment of hatred and evil that shows up throughout time in different forms. It's not a personal vendetta or revenge or whatever. It's just evil for the sake of evil. What reason has Link ever had to be the hero of time? He just is. That's his purpose. In another series your complaint might be legitimate, but this is pretty much how it is in the series. Ganon is the embodiment of evil that's all there is to it.

WRITING.TITLE: Soundtrack is a huge disappointment
WRITING.TEXT:
I just now opened up the soundtrack that came with the special edition after putting in about 100 hrs. I was really disappointed to see that the Hyrule Castle music wasn't in there at all, nor was the music from the Lost Woods. It's mostly just the music you hear traveling around and battle music.
Here's the tracklist:
Main theme
Field(Day)
Battle(Field)
Shrine
Battle(Shrine)
Riding(Day)
Riding(Night)
The Temple of Time
Guardian Battle
Talus Battle
Hinox Battle
Stables
Kass's Theme
Kakariko Village(Day)
Kakariko Village(Night)
Goron City(Day)
Goron City(Night)
Zora's Domain(Day)
Zora's Domain(Night)
Gerudo Town(Day)
Gerudo Town(Night)
Main Theme(Live)
Overall the music in this game isn't memorable, but the few gems that are in the game aren't even on the soundtrack.I'm pretty irritated by this.
Edit: Seem to be getting downvotes, which I understand because I'm criticizing the game, but I wanna be clear I don't hate the soundtrack. I enjoyed Kass's theme, the music of each respective race and I enjoy the music while I'm playing, but lets be real the soundtrack isn't iconic. I'm more or less disappointed with the actual soundtrack that came with the special edition. It's missing some of the best music in the game.

I'm not talking "holy shit this game is so realistic that I have to control my bowel movements." But yeah, I feel immersed in the game when I'm wearing Rito armor in the mountains, or wearing climbing gear to climb a mountain, or I need to wear the desert set or gerudo set to withstand the heat. It's not perfectly immersive but I'm willing to give up certain elements of immersion for better gameplay and mechanics. I can forget that I changed gear midair because it would just be really inconvenient if I couldn't change clothes instantly. I don't think about it. If i'm just running around a mountaintop naked or I'm in Death Valley wearing Rito armor, there is a huge dissonance between the world and the player.
Unless they're really struggling I wouldn't offer. It's not worth it if they get the wrong impression.
